ReportSection.name: Program Description
ReportSection.title: 2017 AGE-WELL Catalyst Program
ReportSection.ReportItem:
AGE-WELL’s Catalyst Program supports innovative research projects aimed at generating, promoting or accelerating economic and social benefit in the field of technology and aging. This program is essential to the long term direction and future of AGE-WELL.

The Catalyst program is the first stage in AGE-WELL’s innovation pipeline and will support early-stage, scalable research projects including pilot studies, feasibility studies and novel approaches that are aligned with AGE-WELL’s mission and vision. This program is for projects with new ideas that are challenging the status quo; projects that can demonstrate strong potential for real-world impact, that are mobilizing a research team and planning, or developing project that will closely address problems/needs.

It is expected that Catalyst projects will lead to major new research initiatives, either as part of AGE-WELL or through other granting agencies. Successful projects may be suitable for future AGE-WELL investment as they progress along the innovation pipeline, following the initial one year investment. To be eligible for continued funding through AGE-WELL, project deliverable at the end of the grant term must provide justification for advancing the project through a renewal of Catalyst funding or by funding through other AGE-WELL programs (e.g. post-discovery accelerator program). See Project Deliverables and Potential for Continued Funding.

Award Value and Term

Up to $50,000 over 12 months. Renewable for one year.

Deadline: March 8th, 2017, 5:00 pm EST.

Eligibility

  • The competition is open to researchers based at Canadian institutions working in the field of technology and aging. AGE-WELL uses the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) definition of “independent researchers” when defining eligible grant holders (see http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/34190.html).
  • The applicant’s host institution must be eligible to hold Tri-Council funding. Canadian universities and investigators who are not already members of AGE-WELL will be required to sign onto the Network Agreement prior to receiving funds.
  • Investigators may not hold more than one AGE-WELL Catalyst grant in the same fiscal year.
  • Catalyst funds cannot be used for activities funded through other AGE-WELL research competitions (e.g. activities that are part of an AGE-WELL Core Research Project).
  • Investigators will normally be expected to include partner organizations in their projects, including as part of any dissemination or commercialization planning. Such organizations should be described in the application, even where the partnership is at a very early stage of development. For reporting purposes, all partnership activities should be quantified in the application.
  • Proposals will ideally demonstrate some level of additional cash and/or in-kind contributions from industry or community partners or describe a plan to secure such contributions. There is no minimum contribution level required for the Catalyst program.

Application and Review Process:

Applications will be accepted through AGE-WELL’s Forum Research Portal.

  1. Access the Catalyst Program section of the Forum Research Portal.
    • All current AGE-WELL Network Investigators have Forum accounts and can access the Catalyst Program application materials through the 'My Applications' tab visible when the log into Forum.
    • Applicants who are not already AGE-WELL Network Investigators must first request access to Forum by emailing info@agewell-nce.ca to request an account.  Accounts will be set up within 24 hours (maximum) of receiving the request. Once an account is set up, access application materials through the 'My Applications' tab visible upon login.
  2. Complete the information in each section, uploading attachments as requested. The narrative sections of the application should not exceed 5 pages.
  3. It is critical that AGE-WELL research investments support the potential for “real world impact”. A Relevancy Review will be carried out by network stakeholders (older adults and caregivers) to determine the potential for uptake and impact if funded by AGE-WELL. Results of the relevancy review will be taken into consideration by the Research Management Committee during the Scientific Review of the proposal.

Potential for Continued Funding and Project Deliverables

The Catalyst program is about demonstrating long-term viability and preparing for the next steps in the innovation pipeline. All teams who anticipate making applications for further AGE-WELL funding will be expected to produce specific and measurable deliverables at the conclusion of their project:

  • Problem/solution statement providing evidence of co-creation with key stakeholders over the term of the project. This should emphasize the need/problem/aspiration of stakeholder(s).  "Solutions" should be high level and noncommittal as to technology platform at this stage.
  • Environmental scan and/or literature review to provide an overview of the state of the art with respect to the problem/solution statement and will provide the justification for advancing the project.
  • Research project outline for next steps that would map out approach and likely methods for how a follow-up R&D project would be carried out.
  • Preliminary business case addressing either knowledge mobilization and/or commercialization plans; business canvas and basic market analysis.

Key Contact:

Questions about the Catalyst Program should be directed to Jeanie Zabukovec, AGE-WELL Research and Partnerships Administrator (Jeanie@agewell-nce.ca).

ReportSection.ReportItem: 1. Project lead(s):  {$item}
Institution:  {$item}
Project Title:  {$item}

• Provide a 300-word lay summary that includes a problem statement, research purpose and anticipated impact(s) of the project. This summary will be provided to network stakeholders in order to facilitate a Relevancy Review to determine the potential for uptake and impact if funded. This description will also be used for future communications if the proposal is successful.) {$item}

ReportSection.ReportItem: • The proposed project is best aligned with AGE-WELL {$item} (WP descriptions are available here: www.agewell-nce.ca)
If you have selected “Other” and think that the proposed project falls outside of AGE-WELL’s current WP structure, please provide a justification for this: {$item}

ReportSection.title: PART 1 - Narrative Application
ReportSection.name: Narrative Application
ReportSection.ReportItem: Section 1- Overview

1. Background, Research Question, and/or Objectives - description of problem area and rationale. Cleary state the underlying hypothesis (if applicable) and why this proposal is considered to have the potential to improve the lives of Canadian seniors. This should provide evidence of co-creation with key stakeholders over the term of the project. {$item}
• Methodological Approach - study design, population, design methodology, data analysis, statistics, etc. {$item}

• Relevance to AGE-WELL vision and goals - Describe the relevance and the importance of the proposed project to AGE-WELL’s mission and vision and how the project aligns with at least one of AGE-WELL Workpackages. Identify how the proposed study meets the specific objectives of the Catalyst Program to foster novel, innovative projects demonstrating potential for significant socio-economic benefits related to the aging population. {$item}
Section 2 – Innovation and Impact
1. Novelty and originality {$item}

• Potential for Knowledge Mobilization and/or Commercialization - Describe the opportunities for knowledge translation and exchange and/or technology transfer or commercialization of the research proposed. If there are specific companies or organizations that will be involved, list them in section 3 of this application (Partnerships) and ensure that a letter of support is included. {$item}
• Social Innovation: Potential implications and practical benefits for the aged population What are practical benefits to the wider community? How will these be achieved? {$item}
• Scientific Innovation - What are the key scientific outputs from this research? How will these be communicated to the scientific and/or knowledge-using communities? {$item}
Section 3 – Research Plan

1. Timeline of Research Deliverables & Milestones - Describe the research milestones and deliverables over the duration of the project. Identify all feasibility issues, challenges and limitations, and what the investigative team will do to overcome them. Include a summary of how this project will be managed and deliverables tracked. {$item}

• Future plans to ensure sustainability of this study - Describe any future funding opportunities or collaborations that will help to ensure the project objectives are met following the AGE-WELL funding period. {$item}
Section 4 – Project team and Networking

1. Project Networking and Engagement - across disciplines, research sites, and sectors. Projects must represent a collaborative effort of different Investigators in more than one discipline and at more than one Institution and with involvement or partners and stakeholders from other sectors. {$item}

• Development of HQP - AGE-WELL funded proposals must contribute to the development of Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP) through their inclusion as fully involved team members. Briefly summarize the number and level of HQP required and the experience/expertise afforded by involvement in Network-funded research. Specify expected contributions to HQP studies. {$item}

• Collaborators/Partners and added value of the collaboration - Part 3 of this application will include letter(s) of support confirming quantified contributions. Partner contributions should also appear in the Budget spreadsheet. {$item}

• Other Funding - Please provide details of other funding applied for that could leverage/support your AGE-WELL Network proposal. Funding should be described by individual, for the Project Leader, all other Principal Investigators, and all Co-Investigators, for grants currently planned to be applied for, being applied for, pending, about to be submitted, and all grants received, for the entire period covered by this application. {$item}

ReportSection.title: Partnerships and Letters
ReportSection.name: Partnerships and Letters
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Investigator Bio

Please submit a brief bio (2 page maximum) for each named investigator from Part 2, highlighting experience and activities relevant to the application.

{$item}

ReportItem.labels:
Partner Organization/ Research Receptor|Potential Conflict of Interest|Role in Project and Specific
Use of Contribution in Project|Nature of Contribution|Contribution Amount (CDN$)

ReportSection.ReportItem:
List each organization that will partner in the project, their specific roles (i.e. research receptor, knowledge user, financial/in-kind support), and the cash and in-kind contributions anticipated from the partner(s) to the project. All financial information provided in the budget in the Budget and Activities section should also appear in the pertinent areas of the project budget, and individuals from these organizations that will be participating as project team members should also be listed in the Project Team List.

Please provide a letter of support on the letterhead of each eligible partner detailing the extent of their collaboration and/or cash and in-kind contribution towards the project. The letter should specifically include reference to AGE-WELL, the proposed project, and any conditions placed on funding.

Where a researcher has a “financial interest” (as defined by NCE Conflict of Interest Guidelines) in a partner, the potential conflict of interest should be declared. This does not preclude the partnership in any way, but provides transparency during the review process. Please see AGE-WELL Conflict of Interest Policy and Guidelines available on AGE-WELL’s website for further information.

Please see Application Instructions for guidance on allowable expenses and eligible partners and contributions.

{$item}
